title: Man Utd's wage bill is the highest ever reported by a Premier League club
text:

While Manchester United's performance on the pitch is on the decline, the struggling club's latest financial results have revealed that their wage bill isn't.

In fact, the Premier League giants - currently enduring their worst start to a league campaign in 30 years - have racked up a staggering wage list that is the highest ever reported by an English top-flight side.

The eye-watering £332million yearly wage bill is an all-time high in English football and has grown by an incredible £100m (43 per cent) in the last three years alone.

The figures have been released by Swiss Ramble, a respected financial blogger, after United became the first Premier League club to publish 2018/19 financial results.

Their growing costs aren't helped by top earners including David De Gea, who recently signed a new £375,000-a-week deal, and Paul Pogba, the French World Cup winner who collects £290,000 a week.

(Image: PA)

Notably, their wage bill has shot up £36million (12% per cent) from £296m to £332m after a huge overhaul of the first-team squad over the last 12 months.

That wasn't help by an additional seven months of Alexis Sanchez, believed to have been on around £400,000 a week, before the Chilean finally sealed a loan move to Inter Milan in the summer.

The figures also highlight the huge sums of money United have invested in the squad over the last nine years, with the club's 2012 wage list only the third highest in England, behind Manchester City and Chelsea.

But, having struggled for success since Sir Alex Ferguson called time on his glittering managerial spell in 2013, Old Trafford chiefs have splashed the cash in a desperate bid to bring success back to the red half of Manchester.

(Image: EMPICS Sport)

And, although fellow Premier League giants are yet to release their latest figures, United are miles above their rivals when you compare the 2017-18 figures.

The most recent financial results are: Liverpool £264m, Manchester City £260m, Chelsea £244m, Arsenal 223m and Tottenham £148m,

United fans will be concerned by the results, which cover a disappointing season in which they finished sixth in the league - once again missing out on Champions League football - and were eliminated from Europe's elite competition in the quarter-finals by Barcelona .

United, once the dominant force in English football, have made their worst start to a Premier League campaign in 30 years and dropped to 12th in the table, two points above the relegation zone, after last weekend's 1-0 defeat at Newcastle.

(Image: Getty Images)

Solskjaer is the fourth permanent manager to take charge since Ferguson retired in 2013, with the 20-times English champions enduring mixed fortunes under David Moyes, Louis van Gaal and Jose Mourinho despite spending heavily on players.

The manager, who sanctioned the departures of Sanchez and Romelu Lukaku in the close season, is trying to rebuild the side with a greater emphasis on youth.

As such, the club signed centre back Harry Maguire, right back Aaron Wan-Bissaka and winger Daniel James before the season started.

But their decline has continued - and the worrying increase in wages will no doubt cause further anger among the frustrated United faithful.
description: Manchester United - currently enduring their worst start to a league campaign in 30 years - have racked up a staggering wage list
